course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: You have a goal but keep drifting between different approaches. What is a good first step to get focused?
options: Describe the end state in concrete, observable terms, then work backwards to identify today's first move
Start with whatever is urgent or feels most pressing
List all possible actions without prioritization or filtering
Set a distant deadline and hope motivation arrives

questions.question: A product team wants to launch a new feature in 6 months. They start by describing what success looks like on launch day, then work backwards to today. What is this approach called?
options: Working backwards: starting from the desired result and reverse-engineering the path step by step
Planning from today forward only without considering the end state or desired outcome
Reviewing past projects only without forward planning or goal-setting
Asking the client what they want last without planning ahead or defining success

questions.question: After working backwards from your goal, you have identified several possible first steps. Which one should you choose?
options: The step that gets you one notch toward the end state and can be tested soon
The most impressive-sounding action regardless of actual impact or testability
Whatever is already in the backlog without prioritization or evaluation
The cheapest option regardless of effectiveness or alignment with the goal

questions.question: Why is a vague end state (e.g. "we will be better") a problem?
options: You cannot work backwards reliably; the path and first move stay fuzzy
It motivates people more
It is easier to communicate
It has no effect on outcomes or learning

questions.question: Skipping steps in the backwards chain tends to result in:
options: Missing dependencies or an unrealistic first move
Faster execution without proper planning
More creativity without structure
Lower cost but reduced effectiveness

questions.question: A team's goal is "improve customer satisfaction." How should they make this end state concrete before planning the path?
options: Define what "done" looks like in observable terms: e.g. "80% of customers rate us 4+ stars"
Write a vision statement only without measurable criteria or testable outcomes
Copy another company's goal without adapting to their context or situation
Let the team interpret freely without alignment or shared understanding of success

questions.question: A team has worked backwards from their goal and identified three steps. What should they do next?
options: Use the step that reaches from today toward that end as the first move and execute it
Document the full chain and wait for approval before taking any action
Start from the end and hope the team catches up without clear guidance or structure
Revise the end state again without testing whether the path actually works
